- http://logs.openstack.org/16099/6/check/gate-nova-pylint/3844 : SUCCESS (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-12-03 19:32:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

question inline. Otherwise lgtm.

One other feature: I wonder if we should be returning a url to the volume instead of the image to the user. I don't think there is any way for the user to know to see which volume he booted from. Perhaps we need an extension to show the bdm. We could present it as drives attached to the instance.

  [
    {'source': '<image_url'>', 'current': 'local'}
    {'source': 'blank', 'current': 'ephemeral'}
    {'source': '<image_url'>', 'current': '<volume_url>'}
  ]

something like that the 'local' value could also be some sort of internal url representing the file backing."}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-12-04 10:17:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Thanks Nikola for the complete responses to the issues raised. 

Yes, I agree this patch should proceed as the first step.

Cheers,
Eoghan'}, {'account_id': 5511, 'date': '2012-12-04 16:16:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: (2 inline comments)

Vish,

Please see inline comments.

Thanks,

N.'}, {'account_id': 5511, 'date': '2012-12-04 16:53:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Vish,

Re the feature proposal - it is very valid, and I will add it to the blueprint. 

Currently it is possible to see which volumes are attached to which instances in cinder however it seems very usefull to have nova give this information too.'}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-12-04 17:13:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

ndipanov: thanks for the feedback! I'm fine with this

I do want to ask, are you intending to add the functionality Vish mentioned to this patch, or a follow up?"}, {'account_id': 5511, 'date': '2012-12-04 17:29:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Matt,

I plan to add it in a subsequent patch, and I added it to the blueprint improve-boot-from-volume I plan to use to track the work on this.

ATM if an instance is started from a volume with no image, the ImageRef the serevers show api call returns will be empty so it is not *totally* confusing even as is - but definitely can be improved.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-12-05 00:21:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

commit_message:
Boot from volume without image supplied

This patch allows for booting instances without supplying an image if
there is block device mapping supplied. It makes changes to nova API
and
compute services to handle requests that do not have any image
supplied.

Also it makes rescue and rebuild work with instances started from
volume.

Finally the patch introduces tests to make sure the system acts as
expected, and in the process fixes and refactors some old tests to make
them test for cases this new functionality can introduce.

This patch is intended to be a proof of concept and a first step
towards
a more cleaner interface for booting from volumes, outlined in
https://etherpad.openstack.org/grizzly-boot-from-volumes.

This patch also introduces a slight modification of the nova API so I
am flagging it with DocImpact. The change is that if the os-volumes
extension is used ImageRef does not need to be supplied to the create
server API call provided there is block_device_mapping provided.

Also note that this is the first step towards introducing a 'volume'
parameter
for starting instances which will replace the somewhat unintuitive
block_device_mapping (they will still be used but not for the boot
device).

This patch is coupled with I5ba9b0f35a5084aa91eca260f46cac83b8b6591e
that provides changes to the nova client.

Implements: blueprint improve-boot-from-volume
Fixes bug #1008622

Change-Id: I530760cfaa5eb0cae590c7383e0840c6b3f896b9

commit_message:
Allow newer boto library versions

Change the boto dependency specification in pip-requires to just 'boto'
without version restriction, as it was before the build issue.

Change-Id: If6c317ffce867f9e544e47c5b0e4b1f2fe9f082f

anonymous account access should be removed. Added a note

commit_message:
Add a note about removing mysql anonymous accts

fixes bug 1085426

As in the bug report, to secure the mysql installation,
anonymous account access should be removed. Added a note
with these instructions.

Change-Id: Id7816e569b1d9d8cad6345d5b456f766a7946dca

Some replies to Yong's comments on patch set 6, while I re-review the latest patch set"}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-12-04 21:27:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: (18 inline comments)

Hi Yong.

Some comments inline.
The work is not pretty much aligned with the DHCP agent (at least this is what I gather).

I probably missed this in the review, but when floating ips are updated, you send a routers_updated notification to the agents, which seems to invoke process_routers. Does that function also update NAT rules for floating IPs? Or is that done elsewherE?'}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-12-04 21:27:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Hi Yong

Good job!
Why we can't use service.py and manager.py in openstack-common?"}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-12-04 21:27:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

You are right. manager.py isn't in the oslo now.
We can move later."}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-12-04 21:27:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: (18 inline comments)

Thank salvatore.
There are some differences than the dhcp agent.
1: we use nova's standard server start up framework so that we can get a consistent view across the openstack projects.
and we will have same set of option values.
2: we will adjust dhcp agent to fit in this framework to prepare for quantum scheduler and multi host and instances BP.
3: regarding algorithm:
l3 agent sends out:
sync_router when starting:
get_external_network_id if needed.
quantum l3 enalbed plugin sends out:
router_deleted
router_updated

I keep the l3 agent does not bug the quantum server as possible as I can. and keep the current l3 agent codes changed as little as possible.
I admit we can improve, for example we notify the agent with small chuck of data, not the big router. I.E. when floatingip associates or disassociates, notify the agent just the floating ip data, we can use it to interface addition and deletion too.
But I hope we can do it later."}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-12-04 21:27:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Salvatore,
the update notification will update NAT rule for floatingip too in l3 agent's process_router_floating_ips, which is called by process_router"}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-12-04 21:27:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

I cannot see manager.py in https://github.com/openstack/oslo-incubator i.e. the openstack-common yet.

My manager.py is adapted from nova (with little modification). So if the oslo has one later, we can move to there.'}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-12-04 21:27:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-12-04 21:27:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-12-04 21:27:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

Hi Yong,

I've looked again at your patch, my comments and your explanations.
I would love to approve it but...

I still have some issues - please don't hate me.

The non-important ones are:
- The router_updated notification is sending out a lot of data. For instance, if I update a floating IP all router interfaces are still being sent. I think it can be improved in a fairly simple way, but we do not need to this in this patch. I just want to hear your opinion, and see if you also think the payload content can be optimized.
- Still in order to optimize payload data, there are probably some info we might avoid sending  (device_id and device_owner for instance). Also, subnet info could be collapsed in fixed_ips
- The topic is just l3_agent. So if we run without namespaces, with multiple routers, will we still be able to run 1 agent per router? I've not tested this bit,  it would be a shame to lose this capability. Assuming it can still work, is the message being casted to all agents?

And finally the only serious one we should address, if confirmed.
I've noticed that when a floating ip is created, the corresponding info is not being sent. I think this happens because we generated the data to send before the data are written into the database.

It would be great if you could have a look at this to confirm or deny this behaviour.

The -1 is just to avoid other core devs from approving the patch before you can answer me.

Thanks again,
Salvatore"}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-12-04 21:27:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Hi,
All of my comments have been addressed.
Tested with namespaces enabled and disable on ubuntu and fedora (different implementations for message bus).
Thanks
Gary'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-12-04 21:27:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 2592, 'date': '2012-12-04 21:27:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(17 inline comments)

This is getting a lot closer to the finish line.  I've got a few items that I consider blockers:

1) There seems to be a lot of common code that was copied from Oslo into Quantum classes instead of adding the proper modules.  We should copy the correct modules into quantum.openstack.common where possible to avoid forking that code that requires extra maintenance.

2) There are a few items that I think we need to consider where they are placed within the source.  

I've included specific comments inline."}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-12-04 21:27:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-12-04 21:27:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: (17 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-12-04 21:27:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13:

1.The router_updated notification is sending out a lot of data. For instance, if I update a floating IP all router interfaces are still being sent. I think it can be improved in a fairly simple way, but we do not need to this in this patch. I just want to hear your opinion, and see if you also think the payload content can be optimized.
[gongysh] I have said we can improve it as we going. THis patch keeps the original agent as possible as I can. We can send floating, interface notification later.

2.Still in order to optimize payload data, there are probably some info we might avoid sending (device_id and device_owner for instance). Also, subnet info could be collapsed in fixed_ips
[gongysh] same as before, keep the original agent codes.
we can merge them into normal fixed_ips so that it contains cidr, gateway and so on.
3.
The topic is just l3_agent. So if we run without namespaces, with multiple routers, will we still be able to run 1 agent per router? I've not tested this bit, it would be a shame to lose this capability. Assuming it can still work, is the message being casted to all agents?
[gongysh] Yes, you cannot for now. after this patch, we will introduce multiple agents features, remember I have a host field in RPC message?"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-12-04 21:27:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: Works for me

I guess you're not seeing anymore the disassociate floating ip issue?"}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-12-04 21:27:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 20:

I still have the problem that when a floating IP is created and associated at the same time, the corresponding NAT rules are not created.

It seems the reason is still the one I highligthed in my last round of review.
The problem is not intermittent:

quantum floatingip-create <ext-net> --port-id <port-id>

- no dnat rules show up, agent does not receive anything

quantum floatingip-disassociate <floatingip-id>
quantum floatingip-associate <floatingip-id> <port-id>

...and then the rule show up!
Can you tell me what am I doing wrong?

Also, I deleted a port associated with a floating IP, which should trigger disassociate_floating_ips which in turn will cause the router_updated message to be sent. However, after deleting a port, the SNAT/DNAT rules are still there:

Chain quantum-l3-agent-PREROUTING (1 references)
target     prot opt source               destination         
DNAT       all  --  0.0.0.0/0            172.24.4.227         to:10.0.1.3

Chain quantum-l3-agent-float-snat (1 references)
target     prot opt source               destination         
SNAT       all  --  10.0.1.3             0.0.0.0/0            to:172.24.4.227

A funny is that if I then create a port I can access it through the floating IP, even if it is not associated (as 10.0.1.3 has been recycled and assigned).

I am not giving a -1, as it seems I'm the only one having problems, so it is likely I am the problem. However, an answer would be welcome."}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-12-04 21:27:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-12-04 21:27:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 20:

I was not actually looking at the created rules (my bad) but was seeing if traffic was getting to the floating IP.
I'll go over your comments.
Thanks for catching these."}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-12-04 21:27:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20:

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-12-04 21:27:11.000000000', 'message': "l3 agent rpc

On one hand, we sync router data (including routers,
their gw ports, interfaces and floatingips) from l3_agent
to quantum server periodically if needed.

On the other hand, we notify l3 agent from quantum server when
we delete or update a router's stuff, such as floating IP,
interface and gwport and router itself.

blueprint rpc-for-l3-agent
bug #1080286

Change-Id: I60f3081975fc7164b22f9e9fa941e702a3f4c663
"}, {'created': '2012-12-04 21:27:11.000000000', 'message': "l3 agent rpc

On one hand, we sync router data (including routers,
their gw ports, interfaces and floatingips) from l3_agent
to quantum server periodically if needed.

On the other hand, we notify l3 agent from quantum server when
we delete or update a router's stuff, such as floating IP,
interface and gwport and router itself.

blueprint rpc-for-l3-agent

commit_message:
l3 agent rpc

On one hand, we sync router data (including routers,
their gw ports, interfaces and floatingips) from l3_agent
to quantum server periodically if needed.

On the other hand, we notify l3 agent from quantum server when
we delete or update a router's stuff, such as floating IP,
interface and gwport and router itself.

blueprint rpc-for-l3-agent
bug #1080286

Change-Id: I60f3081975fc7164b22f9e9fa941e702a3f4c663

commit_message:
Start updating documentation for V2 API

Move the web API documentation into the 'webapi'
subdirectory to avoid conflicts with the auto-generated
'api' directory contents. Create a v2 doc file
as a placeholder until the automatic documentation
features of WSME are more complete.

blueprint api-server-pecan-wsme

Change-Id: Ide11ad0b4cebb29318b8bb977bc5165334e22a2c
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-12-04 12:03:15.000000000', 'message': 'Implement V2 API with Pecan and WSME

This changeset reimplements the API
using Pecan and WSME instead of Flask.
The work is started with a project
directory generated by pecan, and is
moved into the main source tree during a
later commit.

Pecan uses "object dispatch" instead of
declared routes. The controller classes
are chained together to implement the
API.  Most of what we have are simple
REST lookups, but a few cases required
custom methods.

WSME is used to define types of inputs
and outputs for each controller method.
The WSME layer handles serizlization and
deserialization in several formats. In
our case, only JSON and XML are
configured.

There are a few small changes to the
return types in the API, as well as to
error handling. Now all errors are
returned as JSON messages made up of a
mapping containing the key
'error_message' and the text of the
error. This will later be enhanced to
include XML support for XML requests.

blueprint api-server-pecan-wsme

Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>
Change-Id: I1b99a16de68f902370a8999eca073c56f9f14865

commit_message:
Implement V2 API with Pecan and WSME

This changeset reimplements the API
using Pecan and WSME instead of Flask.

Pecan uses "object dispatch" instead of
declared routes. The controller classes
are chained together to implement the
API.  Most of what we have are simple
REST lookups, but a few cases required
custom methods.

WSME is used to define types of inputs
and outputs for each controller method.
The WSME layer handles serizlization and
deserialization in several formats. In
our case, only JSON and XML are
configured.

There are a few small changes to the
return types in the API, as well as to
error handling. Now all errors are
returned as JSON messages made up of a
mapping containing the key
'error_message' and the text of the
error. This will later be enhanced to
include XML support for XML requests.

This change also moves the script for
starting the V1 API to a new name and
replaces it with a script that starts
the V2 API. There is an open
bug/blueprint to fix that so both
versions of the API are loaded.

blueprint api-server-pecan-wsme

Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>
Change-Id: I1b99a16de68f902370a8999eca073c56f9f14865

commit_message:
Make policy.json not filesystem location specific.

The interaction between the test suite and the policy.json file
is problematic, because it imposes an operational assumption that
the tests are running with the curdir set to nova/tests. There is
no other reason to need to be located in that directory.

Part of blueprint grizzly-testtools.

Change-Id: I863dac815a768a78fa84d632e5f77ed0f4f599b2

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-30 16:10:16.000000000', 'message': "drop_privileges should also set HOME

E.g. if HOME is not set, swift-proxy will create the
keystone_signing file not in HOME but in /root.
This is because the swift user doesn't have a shell
in /etc/passwd and so it doesn't set environment variables
when impersonating.

Change-Id: I3013007e0dadf6ddccc176e142b7c78c5d63a351
"}, {'created': '2012-12-04 12:20:35.000000000', 'message': "drop_privileges should also set HOME

keystone_signing file not in HOME but in /root.
This is because the swift user doesn't have a shell
in /etc/passwd and so it doesn't set environment variables
when impersonating.

Change-Id: I3013007e0dadf6ddccc176e142b7c78c5d63a351
"}]
commit_message:
drop_privileges should also set HOME

E.g. if HOME is not set, swift-proxy will create the
keystone_signing file not in HOME but in /root.
This is because the swift user doesn't have a shell
in /etc/passwd and so it doesn't set environment variables
when impersonating.

Change-Id: I3013007e0dadf6ddccc176e142b7c78c5d63a351

commit_message:
Revert "Set the rabbit_durable_queues to match local consumers"

This reverts commit 71cf53a9f60176419732f3ecbbce11c75190c059.

The attempt to set the queue durability for Glance notifications always
sets the queues to durable. We are reverting this until a refined
approach is available.

Change-Id: I469e5149d21e3fcdd409da8114d5ccef1ff1243c

subject: Allow optional, temporary healthcheck failure.
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-12-04 00:31:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build successful

- http://logs.openstack.org/17430/1/check/gate-swift-merge/1377 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/17430/1/check/gate-swift-docs/1001 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/17430/1/check/gate-swift-pep8/1144 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/17430/1/check/gate-swift-python26/1249 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/17430/1/check/gate-swift-python27/1251 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/17430/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/20946 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-12-04 00:45:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

More for my curiosity than anything else; but why doesn't 'swift-init proxy shutdown' (graceful shutdown) work for this already? I realize it results in connection refusals rather than 503s, but the load balancers I'm aware of would treat both as reason for removal from the pool."}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2012-12-04 01:03:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

We'd like the server out of the pool until we're sure it's okay (upgraded or whatever).  Just gracefully stopping the proxy wouldn't keep it from getting back into the pool on a server reboot or something similar.

Also, we use Upstart to keep the services running and its SIGHUP support has been pretty crappy in practice.  Sending a SIGHUP outside of Upstart works for a graceful /restart/, but AFAIK, you can't say, "don't kill running ones, but don't start new ones, either", then send the SIGHUP.  With an external mechanism like this patch's, we can get the LB off our back, then do a graceful restart, wait for all the old server PIDs to go away (existing connections), then continue with the maintenance/upgrade. 

A persistent stay-out mechanism also allows for a local-server sanity-check before putting it back into the LB pool.  I.e. you touch the file, wait, stop, upgrade, start, test, remove the file.

Obviously, if something goes off the rails, it will need human intervention because the file is "sticky", but that's better than something like a power-cycle allowing the server back into the LB pool if it's not fully healthy (partially-upgrade or whatever).'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-12-04 01:13:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Ah, gotcha, power cycle and such. I guess we've always just reconfigured the load balancers for such occurrences to date. This is an easier method since it's a single point instead of reconfiguring all the balancers. Gotcha."}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-12-04 02:38:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Minor nits:

The "pipeline" keyword and "use" keywords in filter sections don't have defaults. Maybe a reword "The default is|should be" to "This is normally".

Maybe make the text/plain bodies from healthcheck end in \r\n just because it's nicer to command lines?

Maybe explain better how/why this would be used? Might be more text than it's worth though.

Maybe make "disable_path" have the default of "/etc/swift/healthcheck-503"? Seems that once you realize you need it, you realize you never configured it.'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2012-12-04 17:05:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> The "pipeline" keyword and "use" keywords in filter sections don't have defaults. Maybe a reword "The default is|should be" to "This is normally".

Sure, I didn't add that, per se, just edited those (quite out of date) man pages in the spirit in which they currently existed.  (I assume you're referring to the copy of the manpages--if not, please let me know.)  I'll fix those up.

 > Maybe make the text/plain bodies from healthcheck end in \r\n just because it's nicer to command lines?

I would prefer to not change the existing healthcheck body at all, because load balancers may be checking their (exact) contents (ours is, for instance).  This would be a backwards-compatibility issue.  Besides, the health-check URL's body is really designed for machine consumption, so it doesn't seem too bad to not have \r\n in there.  Then, given an unchanged "OK", I opted for consistency in the body when the disable_path file is present.

 > Maybe explain better how/why this would be used? Might be more text than it's worth though.

I thought the copy in proxy-server.conf-sample was sufficient:

 # This facility may be used to temporarily remove a Swift node from a load
 # balancer pool during maintenance or upgrade (remove the file to allow the
 # node back into the load balancer pool).

and I didn't see any references to healthcheck in other docs (deployer/admin guide).  Can you recommend another doc location where additional details could go?  Deployer's guide somewhere?

> Maybe make "disable_path" have the default of "/etc/swift/healthcheck-503"? Seems that once you realize you need it, you realize you never configured it.

We thought about that, but I prefered having the feature fully disabled by default and to be "opt-in".  So even the (minuscule) cost of the os.path.exists() would be opt-in-only and if that file for some reason got on the filesystem, operators wouldn't have unexpected behavior start happening.

We're going to use "/etc/swift/PROXY-DISABLED" for ours, so it'll stand out in "ls" output and whatnot.  Though I like your filename's info, so maybe "/etc/swift/PROXY-HEALTHCHECK-DISABLED-503" would be better.  You don't want this file to be innocuous and the more self-documenting, the better ;).'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2012-12-04 17:14:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-12-04 17:34:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build successful

- http://logs.openstack.org/17430/2/check/gate-swift-merge/1383 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/17430/2/check/gate-swift-docs/1007 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/17430/2/check/gate-swift-pep8/1150 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/17430/2/check/gate-swift-python26/1255 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/17430/2/check/gate-swift-python27/1257 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/17430/2/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/21027 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-12-04 17:55:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Gotcha, sounds good and thanks for updating that wording while you were in there.

I don't expect we'll be using this just because our load balancers have such features already, but it's not like this is too complex to maintain as a feature or anything, so...

+2"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-12-04 19:24:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: No score

Starting gate jobs.
https://jenkins.openstack.org/zuul/status'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2012-12-04 19:24:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-12-04 00:17:29.000000000', 'message': 'Allow optional, temporary healthcheck failure.

A deployer may want to remove a Swift node from a load balancer for
maintenance or upgrade.  This patch provides an optional mechanism for
this.  The healthcheck filter config can specify "disable_path" which is
a filesystem path.  If a file is present at that location, the
healthcheck middleware returns a 503 with a body of "DISABLED BY FILE".

So a deployer can configure "disable_path" and then touch that
filesystem path, wait for the proxy to be removed from the load balancer
pool, perform maintenance/upgrade, and then remove the "disable_path"
file.

Also cleaned up the conf file man pages a bit.

Change-Id: I1759c78c74910a54c720f298d4d8e6fa57a4dab4
'}, {'created': '2012-12-04 17:14:58.000000000', 'message': 'Allow optional, temporary healthcheck failure.

A deployer may want to remove a Swift node from a load balancer for
maintenance or upgrade.  This patch provides an optional mechanism for
this.  The healthcheck filter config can specify "disable_path" which is
a filesystem path.  If a file is present at that location, the
healthcheck middleware returns a 503 with a body of "DISABLED BY FILE".

So a deployer can configure "disable_path" and then touch that
filesystem path, wait for the proxy to be removed from the load balancer
pool, perform maintenance/upgrade, and then remove the "disable_path"
file.

Also cleaned up the conf file man pages a bit.

Change-Id: I1759c78c74910a54c720f298d4d8e6fa57a4dab4
'}]
commit_message:
Allow optional, temporary healthcheck failure.

A deployer may want to remove a Swift node from a load balancer for
maintenance or upgrade.  This patch provides an optional mechanism for
this.  The healthcheck filter config can specify "disable_path" which is
a filesystem path.  If a file is present at that location, the
healthcheck middleware returns a 503 with a body of "DISABLED BY FILE".

So a deployer can configure "disable_path" and then touch that
filesystem path, wait for the proxy to be removed from the load balancer
pool, perform maintenance/upgrade, and then remove the "disable_path"
file.

Also cleaned up the conf file man pages a bit.

Change-Id: I1759c78c74910a54c720f298d4d8e6fa57a4dab4

Use the instance_update method on the conductor service for issuing
instance update requests from the compute resource tracker.
Notifications are sent out by conductor, so that was removed from the
resource tracker.

The conductor now also accepts 'launched_on' as a valid key.  A

commit_message:
Use conductor for resourcetracker instance_update.

Use the instance_update method on the conductor service for issuing
instance update requests from the compute resource tracker.
Notifications are sent out by conductor, so that was removed from the
resource tracker.

The conductor now also accepts 'launched_on' as a valid key.  A
duplicate 'host' key in the list of valid keys was removed.

Part of blueprint no-db-compute.

Change-Id: Id4858cc2ab0d128107ea311e2ababef51c2ded83

commit_message:
Access DB values as dict not as attributes. Part 3

We cannot assume nova.db.api will be returning sqlalchemy objects
attributes, instead treat return values as dicts

Part of blueprint db-api-cleanup

Change-Id: Icf45e5475b9d626f7e07efe953615dd82bb69ade

Does nova (or anything else) need to have the usage data in the database? If not, this code would probably be better off living in the ceilometer pollster modules. For example, https://github.com/stackforge/ceilometer/blob/master/ceilometer/compute/libvirt.py#L64'}, {'account_id': 951, 'date': '2012-08-14 09:07:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

We could migrate this code to ceilometer, but my understanding is that ceilometer won't be released till post folsom? and this is a requirement for us for the folsom release. I will volunteer to migrate the code post folsom."}, {'account_id': 951, 'date': '2012-08-14 13:07:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

From metering meeting on 2012-07-19

16:08:46 <dricco> We(hp) have a requirement in folsom to gather volume stats
16:08:56 <dricco> just wanted to tie in with ye guys
16:09:07 <jd___> let me read it :)
16:09:11 <dricco> thx
16:09:29 <jd___> I think that's in our scope, indeed
16:09:33 <jd___> that's great you come to see us
16:09:52 <dricco> :-)
16:09:53 <jd___> we don't have any code to support nova-volume or cinder right now, but we plan to
16:09:58 <jd___> the architecture is in place to do so
16:10:15 <jd___> so the good answer is probably to contribute to ceilometer! ;)
16:10:21 <dricco> ceilometer is post folsom, correct?
16:10:28 <jd___> yes
16:10:45 <jd___> we're trying to get into incubation for G, but it may even be later, we don't know yet
16:10:49 <dricco> so I could do both :-)
16:11:00 <jd___> probably :)
16:11:50 <jd___> how do you think you'll do this? I know we already plan to support nova volume using the notification system
16:11:53 <dricco> i think there is some code already in ceilometer for polling disk io
16:11:59 <jd___> would it be the same in your opinion?
16:12:03 <dricco> but i think it ignores volumes
16:12:13 <jd___> yes there is, but tight to libvirt for now
16:12:19 <jd___> indeed
16:12:27 <jd___> it ignores because we don't know how to request that information actually
16:12:30 <jd___> at least I don't :)
16:13:00 <dricco> it's the same libvirt domblkstat call
16:13:49 <dricco> we're more concerned with what I/O the user sees rather then our backend I/O
16:13:55 <jd___> ok I see
16:14:05 <jd___> so it's polling on attached volume
16:14:21 <dricco> yup, can then one final poll on detach
16:14:34 <dricco> can/and
16:14:37 <lzyeval> so currently there is only diskio? do you have blueprints to implement volume usage info?
16:14:43 <jd___> yes, we probably miss an event to do the final poll indeed
16:15:10 <lzyeval> for instance parsing the qcow2 allocation table to see how much space is left in a volume.
16:15:14 <jd___> dricco: do you now why the current code ignores nova-volume? because it's not something we wanted to do
16:15:42 <jd___> lzyeval: there's no blueprint/bug on our side for this so far, but we would create one for sure
16:16:36 <lzyeval> jd___: great!
16:16:42 <dricco> I'm working on the code for nova folsom at the moment : blueprint - https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/volume-usage-metering
16:16:56 <jd___> lzyeval: do you want to take the action or would you like me to do it?
16:17:04 <dricco> I could use this as a proof of concept for ceilometer?
16:17:16 <jd___> dricco: sure
16:17:25 <dricco> :-)"}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-08-14 15:34:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Sounds good. I think I missed the meeting that week, so I wasn't aware of the discussion. We would be happy to have the code duplicated in ceilometer pre-folsom, if you have time to work on it. :-)"}, {'account_id': 951, 'date': '2012-08-14 15:45:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
Implements volume usage metering.

Add volume usage cache tables to record no. of reads, bytes read,
no. of write, bytes written to a volume.
A periodic task runs in compute manager to query each volume mounted
on a compute host and record its usage, this task also send a
volume.usage notification contains volume usage statistics

Part of blueprint volume-usage-metering

Change-Id: I215ce0c94e9ea5a07e18940802c20d1379b8f6d1

'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2012-12-04 16:37:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

swift doesn't generate .pyscope files, nor is it a common system-level file (like .DS_store). Why not include this in your user .gitignore file?"}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2012-12-04 17:17:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I agree with John.  FWIW, I use pycscope and use the -f option to place the generated file outside the swift tree:

 pycscope.py -R -f ~/.vim/cscope.out ...'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-12-04 18:01:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Today I learned there this PyCscope thing and that Peter wrote it. :)

Anyway, 1 line addition to the .gitignore file to make things a bit easier for him and any others using pycscope seems fine by me.

I think he's proven he's not looking to submit a 1-liner just to get voting privileges or something. :P"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-12-04 18:27:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

Starting gate jobs.
https://jenkins.openstack.org/zuul/status'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2012-12-04 18:27:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 6198, 'date': '2012-12-04 18:31:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

gholt: thanks for the vote. Actually, Dean Hall originally wrote it, and back in 2008 while learning python I fixed it up as a way to learn a bit more about Python and to inspect large code bases easily.

darrell: that works and I would be happy to use that method.

john: I was thinking defensively of the project, where the project's .gitignore list known files that one would not want to mistakenly add to the repository. But from the perspective that you have it seems silly to add this since the normal work flow required to handle openstack swift sources does not include using pycscope.

I am happy to abandon this patch if no other supporters come along. :)"}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2012-12-04 18:40:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Well, Jenkins is working on merging it, so abandonment seems unnecessary at this point. ;)'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-12-04 18:47:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

Live-migration with Ryu plugin doesn't work because the unique constraint of

simplify Ryu plugin.

commit_message:
plugin/ryu: make live-migration work with Ryu plugin

Fixes bug 1085861

Live-migration with Ryu plugin doesn't work because the unique constraint of
PortBinding table is violated as follows.
Now Ryu can handle those informations itself, so remove the table itself and
simplify Ryu plugin.

> ERROR [quantum.api.v2.resource] update failed
> Traceback (most recent call last):
>   File "/quantum/api/v2/resource.py", line 95, in resource
>     result = method(request=request, **args)
>   File "/quantum/api/v2/base.py", line 397, in update
>     obj = obj_updater(request.context, id, **kwargs)
>   File "/quantum/plugins/ryu/ryu_quantum_plugin.py", line 226, in update_port
>     port_binding.dpid, port_binding.port_no))
> InvalidInput: Invalid input for operation: invalid (datapath_id, port_no) requested (00002eab88ec5140, 4), but (0000c2f19014c74a, 1).

Change-Id: I7d993fd01125a27f6bf8e1b3fcac79ddcb8cb361

commit_message:
Move the v2 API into the main source tree

Move the source and tests for the v2 API into the source
tree with the rest of the code and remove the ceilometer_api
directory.

blueprint api-server-pecan-wsme

Change-Id: Ia5458f120237b55ce849def09f8c96a06d25e1d5
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>

commit_message:
Modify API start script to use v2 API

This change moves the script for starting
the V1 API to a new name and replaces it with
a script that starts the V2 API.

Change-Id: Ic626ade25b9df7a52ece063cc047756673e7bd28
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>

Use the new storage API to list meter definitions and return
them from the MetersController.

Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>

messages:
[{'account_id': 4460, 'date': '2012-11-21 17:04:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

For the record, I really think this approach won't scale in the long term. As soon as someone will add a dependency to one of apts/, rpms/ or rpms-suse/ directories, he will likely forget one of the other two directories.

And even more importantly, people will use install_package, without thinking of how the packages are called in all distro.

I think the mapping way (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/14027/ and other patches) will be better in the long term.

But if people prefer it this way, then okay, I'll do my best to keep things working that way too :-)"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-21 17:20:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

commit_message:
Remove __init__.py from bin/ and tools/.

To avoid installation into .../site-packages/quantum via
packages=setuptools.find_packages('.') in setup.py. Both directories
are not Python modules.

Change-Id: I794ad047a5ed52cb040490eb1be54c513c9d1e7c

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-12-03 17:17:35.000000000', 'message': 'Move keystone account creation out of keystone_data.sh

keystone_data.sh is getting unwieldly and increasingly needs
configuration information for services.  Also need the ability
to manipulate HOST/IP information for hosts to handle service
HA/proxy configurations.

Begin moving the creation of service account information into
the service lib files, starting with the common accounts and
keystone itself.

Change-Id: Ie259f7b71983c4f4a2e33ab9c8a8e2b00238ba38
'}, {'created': '2012-12-03 19:48:58.000000000', 'message': 'Move keystone account creation out of keystone_data.sh

keystone_data.sh is getting unwieldly and increasingly needs
configuration information for services.  Also need the ability
to manipulate HOST/IP information for hosts to handle service
HA/proxy configurations.

Begin moving the creation of service account information into
the service lib files, starting with the common accounts and
keystone itself.

Change-Id: Ie259f7b71983c4f4a2e33ab9c8a8e2b00238ba38
'}]
commit_message:
Move keystone account creation out of keystone_data.sh

keystone_data.sh is getting unwieldly and increasingly needs
configuration information for services.  Also need the ability
to manipulate HOST/IP information for hosts to handle service
HA/proxy configurations.

Begin moving the creation of service account information into
the service lib files, starting with the common accounts and
keystone itself.

Change-Id: Ie259f7b71983c4f4a2e33ab9c8a8e2b00238ba38

commit_message:
Document Trusted Compute Pools

Describe how to configure for using Trusted Compute Pools.

Based on:
 *  http://wiki.openstack.org/TrustedComputingPools
 *  https://lists.launchpad.net/openstack/msg18825.html
 (Email from Dale Stewart)

 See also:
 *  http://wiki.openstack.org/OpenAttestation

 This patch also introduces a new chapter called "Security
 Hardening" into the Compute Admin guide. I expect this chapter
 will eventually include discussions on how to integrate with
 other security-related tech, e.g., SELinux/sVirt.

Change-Id: Icf70e5fa7989c3cee820f37dfc5cd1c95a83856c

commit_message:
Add a note about nova-compute.conf in install doc

fixes bug 1064755

As noted in the bug report, the previous sentence referring
to nova-compute.conf was confusing. This change splits it out
and makes it more obvious what can be done.

commit_message:
Note about python deprecation warnings in db sync

fixes 1067472

Some older libraries will produce harmless deprecation warnings
when running the nova-manage db sync. These can be safely ignored.

Change-Id: I6028e22be7b4a93fb5fd81199191557f339cfd85

commit_message:
Add nova.conf sample for use in yum installs

fixes bug 1085411

Duplicates the current nova.conf sample for yum installs
since they need QPID instead of rabbit. Adds some include logic
to refer to the appropriate conf.

Change-Id: Ibba4e7d0b8a1b5e5a8108c2b393b650d63a5f621

subject: Create localhost MySQL accounts for keystone,glance,nova.
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-24 17:37:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build successful

- http://logs.openstack.org/16828/1/check/gate-openstack-manuals-merge/1308 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 321, 'date': '2012-11-24 18:25:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I ended up abandoning a proposed change <https://review.openstack.org/15823>  about removing the anonymous users from MySQL and documented this alternate approach for avoiding a problem with anonymous MySQL users.

However, doing a little more research, it seems that removing anonymous users from MySQL is recommended for production mode. For example, see: 

http://serverfault.com/a/369658/847

Indeed, when you install MySQL on CentOS, it does in fact say:

you can run:
/usr/bin/mysql_secure_installation

which will also give you the option of removing the test
databases and anonymous user created by default.  This is
strongly recommended for production servers.

So, I'm thinking that perhaps we *should* document removing the anonymous users from MySQL in the install guide."}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2012-11-27 14:14:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I think you're right about removing anonymous mysql users. Does this patch preclude doing that in a later patch? If not, Looks good to me."}, {'account_id': 321, 'date': '2012-12-01 15:30:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Anne: We can certainly accept this patch in and add in the instructions on removing the anonymous users in a separate patch, I'll file a bug for that."}, {'account_id': 321, 'date': '2012-12-01 15:38:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Submitted bug https://bugs.launchpad.net/openstack-manuals/+bug/1085426'}, {'account_id': 612, 'date': '2012-12-02 01:18:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Add instructions for finding libvirt version

patch adds instructions on how to find the running version.

Rewrite S3 functional tests

rewrite s3 store functional test coverage using new style of
direct python library calls rather than indirectly testing through
the v1 API.

The original intent was to have a single set of credentials, not multiple. Originally we had multiple, but then consolidated the creds into the identity section. This commit looks good to me.

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-12-03 19:25:55.000000000', 'message': "Fix and simplify arbitrary_string. lp#1085048

The previous behaviour:

	In [4]: data_utils.arbitrary_string(size=3, base_text='test')
	Out[4]: 'tes'

	In [5]: data_utils.arbitrary_string(size=4, base_text='test')
	Out[5]: 'testtesttesttest'

didn't seem sane. Fixed to more sane:
	In [5]: data_utils.arbitrary_string(size=2, base_text='test')
	Out[5]: 'te'

	In [6]: data_utils.arbitrary_string(size=4, base_text='test')
	Out[6]: 'test'

	In [7]: data_utils.arbitrary_string(size=6, base_text='test')
	Out[7]: 'testte

Change-Id: Idf38329b26846b15de929e7d00c6dd1353bde068
"}, {'created': '2012-12-03 23:19:07.000000000', 'message': "Fix and simplify arbitrary_string. lp#1085048

The previous behaviour:

	In [4]: data_utils.arbitrary_string(size=3, base_text='test')
	Out[4]: 'tes'

	In [5]: data_utils.arbitrary_string(size=4, base_text='test')
	Out[5]: 'testtesttesttest'

didn't seem sane. Fixed to more sane:
	In [5]: data_utils.arbitrary_string(size=2, base_text='test')
	Out[5]: 'te'

	In [6]: data_utils.arbitrary_string(size=4, base_text='test')
	Out[6]: 'test'

	In [7]: data_utils.arbitrary_string(size=6, base_text='test')
	Out[7]: 'testte

Change-Id: Idf38329b26846b15de929e7d00c6dd1353bde068
"}]
commit_message:
Fix and simplify arbitrary_string. lp#1085048

The previous behaviour:

	In [4]: data_utils.arbitrary_string(size=3, base_text='test')
	Out[4]: 'tes'

	In [5]: data_utils.arbitrary_string(size=4, base_text='test')
	Out[5]: 'testtesttesttest'

didn't seem sane. Fixed to more sane:
	In [5]: data_utils.arbitrary_string(size=2, base_text='test')
	Out[5]: 'te'

	In [6]: data_utils.arbitrary_string(size=4, base_text='test')
	Out[6]: 'test'

	In [7]: data_utils.arbitrary_string(size=6, base_text='test')
	Out[7]: 'testte

Change-Id: Idf38329b26846b15de929e7d00c6dd1353bde068

[{'created': '2012-12-03 19:01:50.000000000', 'message': 'Convert errors to parsable format

blueprint api-server-pecan-wsme

Disable error the default error handling from pecan
and use a middleware layer to convert error messages to
JSON, with a note to support XML later, too.

Capture stdout from tests so it appears in nose
output near test failures.

Change-Id: I009c56ea2f1be2fc3d37e5df72fafb6899beed07
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Convert errors to parsable format

blueprint api-server-pecan-wsme

Disable error the default error handling from pecan
and use a middleware layer to convert error messages to
JSON, with a note to support XML later, too.

Capture stdout from tests so it appears in nose
output near test failures.

Change-Id: I009c56ea2f1be2fc3d37e5df72fafb6899beed07
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>

commit_message:
Add missing files to python package

The follwing files/directories are missing in MANIFEST.in:

    cinder/db/sqlalchemy/migrate_repo/migrate.cfg
    cinder/api/openstack/volume/schemas/
    cinder/tests/policy.json
    cinder/tests/test_migrations.conf

These are (not only) necessary to run the testsuite from installed
packages. Similar to bug 1084595

Change-Id: I6eaebdf26e43b0e8e13b67ab876001ac43de3eac

[{'created': '2012-11-28 11:48:38.000000000', 'message': 'Add a CLI argument validation utility

blueprint oslo-cliutils

In nova-manage and cinder-manage, we allow command arguments to be
passed as optional or positional arguments.

e.g.

  $> nova-manage floating create 10.0.0.1/28
  $> nova-manage floating create --ip_range 10.0.0.1/28

are equivalent.

Once nova-manage has collected those arguments, it calls the
appropriate command function with them as positional and keyword
arguments. If the user forgets to supply a required argument, they
merely get a TypeError with little useful information.

Improve the usability of these commands using a new utility function
to check that the required arguments have been supplied and raise a
useful exception if not.

Change-Id: If6e4a9f222a30472bbfbcd06859865bd4e37e139

commit_message:
Add a CLI argument validation utility

blueprint oslo-cliutils

In nova-manage and cinder-manage, we allow command arguments to be
passed as optional or positional arguments.

e.g.

  $> nova-manage floating create 10.0.0.1/28
  $> nova-manage floating create --ip_range 10.0.0.1/28

are equivalent.

Once nova-manage has collected those arguments, it calls the
appropriate command function with them as positional and keyword
arguments. If the user forgets to supply a required argument, they
merely get a TypeError with little useful information.

Improve the usability of these commands using a new utility function
to check that the required arguments have been supplied and raise a
useful exception if not.

Change-Id: If6e4a9f222a30472bbfbcd06859865bd4e37e139

commit_message:
Use elevated context in _setup|teardown_network_on_host

Resizing and reverting resizing an instance is not always AdminRequired,
but _setup_network_on_host and _teardown_network_on_host need admin context
to access db.

Fixes bug 1075279

Change-Id: I2c86744910fd7949d4db84fcbba7fe8ca8e38ad0

commit_message:
powervm: add DiskAdapter for local volumes

This change begins moving all block device
related functionality to an abstract DiskAdapter class
The original local logical volume implementation
has been moved into PowerVMLocalVolumeAdapter

Also, this patch opts for on the fly decompression of the
image during the dd copy to the Logical Volume, instead
of running a separate decompress before hand

bp powervm-compute-enhancements

Change-Id: I9ecb81e4351fd3a5c34ab8bce544b8daec353c5a

[{'created': '2012-12-04 01:47:51.000000000', 'message': "Begin adding a simple orchestration layer.

The goal of this layer is to be able to provide a high
level api reception point for which requests for resources
(initially compute resources) will channel through. It will
handle the complex set of transitions (and unraveling) needed
on errors and state transitions so that the components provisioning
and consuming those resources do not have to be complicated by
such knowledge.

This layer will initially be targeted at working this model
into the compute 'create' call where it can be used to show
others of how such a model is better than what exists currently.

Blueprint instance-create-state-machine

See also: http://wiki.openstack.org/RepairingOwnership
See also: http://wiki.openstack.org/SchedulingSplitout (a dependent)

Change-Id: I2cfbd834623153820141e99abe5f1350165af9f2

Continue

Change-Id: Ic1b586200b75a89c5545fc199dfcb95562ba8b3d
"}]
commit_message:
Begin adding a simple orchestration layer.

The goal of this layer is to be able to provide a high
level api reception point for which requests for resources
(initially compute resources) will channel through. It will
handle the complex set of transitions (and unraveling) needed
on errors and state transitions so that the components provisioning
and consuming those resources do not have to be complicated by
such knowledge.

This layer will initially be targeted at working this model
into the compute 'create' call where it can be used to show
others of how such a model is better than what exists currently.

Blueprint instance-create-state-machine

See also: http://wiki.openstack.org/RepairingOwnership
See also: http://wiki.openstack.org/SchedulingSplitout (a dependent)

Change-Id: I2cfbd834623153820141e99abe5f1350165af9f2

Continue

Change-Id: Ic1b586200b75a89c5545fc199dfcb95562ba8b3d

[{'created': '2012-12-04 00:46:35.000000000', 'message': 'Fix rootwrap cfg for src installed metadata proxy.

 * The metadata proxy script will be installed to /usr/local/bin
   if installed from source, rather than the default /usr/bin.
   The filter config needs to be updated to reflect this or
   invacation of the proxy by the l3 agent will fail.

Change-Id: Iccb4133b1ac33a1b9b232c1d68979fe646e1b977
'}]
commit_message:
Fix rootwrap cfg for src installed metadata proxy.

 * The metadata proxy script will be installed to /usr/local/bin
   if installed from source, rather than the default /usr/bin.
   The filter config needs to be updated to reflect this or
   invacation of the proxy by the l3 agent will fail.

Change-Id: Iccb4133b1ac33a1b9b232c1d68979fe646e1b977

commit_message:
Add domain proxies that stop unauthorized actions

This patch introduces domain objects that handle context-based
authorization checks. With this approach, we can eventually remove
ownership checks from the database apis.

Part of implementing bp:glance-domain-logic-layer

Change-Id: I30c7444220013f17dab6479f1b00f1598ab424d0

commit_message:
Deprecate commands and add unified cli replacements.

This is to bring into line with
http://wiki.openstack.org/UnifiedCLI/Mapping

Here is the mapping, as displayed by 'heat help'
    create              DEPRECATED! Use stack-create instead
    delete              DEPRECATED! Use stack-delete instead
    describe            DEPRECATED! Use stack-show instead
    event               DEPRECATED! Use event-show instead
    event-list          List events for a stack
    event-show          Describe the event
    gettemplate         DEPRECATED! Use template-show instead
    list                DEPRECATED! Use stack-list instead
    resource            DEPRECATED! Use resource-show instead
    resource-list       Show list of resources belonging to a stack
    resource-metadata   List resource metadata
    resource-show       Describe the resource
    stack-create        Create the stack
    stack-delete        Delete the stack
    stack-list          List the user's stacks
    stack-show          Describe the stack
    stack-update        Update the stack
    template-show       Get the template for the specified stack
    template-validate   Validate a template with parameters
    update              DEPRECATED! Use stack-update instead
    validate            DEPRECATED! Use template-validate instead
    help                Display help about this program or one of its
                        subcommands.

Change-Id: I1a296de2b935be6cc28fcc49ef8ee7ae333abf1a

messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-29 21:59:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build successful

- http://logs.openstack.org/17166/1/check/gate-swift-merge/1353 : SUCCESS

'}, {'account_id': 6198, 'date': '2012-11-29 22:21:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

This seems to be okay. But is the existing logic correct?

For example, in the container server code, before req.accept.best_match() is invoked, we first check for the format parameter and then override the accept object with that what appears to be a single string object pulled from the constraints module's FORMAT2CONTENT_TYPE dictionary. Is there a way in the code where those objects get turned into swob.Accept() objects?

Beyond that, if we do always end up with an Accept() object for a req.accept field, is it valid to return a 406 response for what is specified by the format parameter? In that case, it would seem that a BadRequest is in order.

Maybe it is not worth handling that nuance?"}, {'account_id': 6198, 'date': '2012-11-29 22:35:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

(7 inline comments)

Further review comments of code you did not change based on reviewing their operation for this commit.'}, {'account_id': 2828, 'date': '2012-11-29 22:40:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Work In Progress

I'm gonna hang on to this for a little more work, because we should probably be serving 406s instead of using default_type when none of the types in the Accept header can be served."}, {'account_id': 2828, 'date': '2012-12-03 19:56:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-12-03 20:15:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

commit_message:
406 if we can't satisfy Accept

The container and account servers should respond with 406 if the Accept header
isn't satisfiable.  This behavior is defined in RFC 2616 section 14.1.

Change-Id: I8a67ccafe33dc70ef4f7794686a54fbc8581f4dc

[{'created': '2012-12-03 22:35:31.000000000', 'message': 'Updates tests to run in other configurations.

* Changes the reddwarf.conf.test flag so "use_nova_server_volume"
  is turned off, as it should be, and fixes a resulting fake mode bug.
* Fixes tests to not check for volume when
  "reddwarf_main_instance_has_volume" is specified in the test config.
* Changes poll_until to reuse Reddwarf implementation instead of
  rewriting it just for the tests.
* Adds tests to confirm its possible to log into a real MySQL instance.
  These are only run for "real mode" in a VM or other environment, but
  it's necessary that they live here.
* Changes the "get_address" method of the InstanceTestInfo object to
  get pulled from the test config (necessary when hitting other
  environments).
* Fixes some bugs in guest agent models.
* Deleted the pagination test. It can't run very quickly in the tox
  fake mode, so there's no point in keeping it here (it still exists
  in Reddwarf-Integration).

Change-Id: I2835762c4180e1ca594b27194564b8f993aa4066
Fixes: bug #1085188

* Changes the reddwarf.conf.test flag so "use_nova_server_volume"

commit_message:
Updates tests to run in other configurations.

* Changes the reddwarf.conf.test flag so "use_nova_server_volume"
  is turned off, as it should be, and fixes a resulting fake mode bug.
* Fixes tests to not check for volume when
  "reddwarf_main_instance_has_volume" is specified in the test config.
* Changes poll_until to reuse Reddwarf implementation instead of
  rewriting it just for the tests.
* Adds tests to confirm its possible to log into a real MySQL instance.
  These are only run for "real mode" in a VM or other environment, but
  it's necessary that they live here.
* Changes the "get_address" method of the InstanceTestInfo object to
  get pulled from the test config (necessary when hitting other
  environments).
* Fixes some bugs in guest agent models.
* Deleted the pagination test. It can't run very quickly in the tox
  fake mode, so there's no point in keeping it here (it still exists
  in Reddwarf-Integration).

Change-Id: I2835762c4180e1ca594b27194564b8f993aa4066
Fixes: bug #1085188

commit_message:
Imports the reddwarf repo tests from their new home.

* Changes redstack to not log to a file when running the fake
  mode daemon (this makes it easier to debug when working from
  a VM and was the old behavior before the tests were added to
  the Reddwarf repo).
* Formats the pagination tests for pep8.
* Removes moved test and utility code.

Change-Id: Idc2e005ca344bb47757d7a70e1370029e6099a48

commit_message:
Added --top option to swift-recon -d

When showing the disk usage dispersion graph it is often useful to
know what those top full drives are so you can do further research.
Now you can run 'swift-recon -d --top 10' to list the top ten devices
by fullness after the usual dispersion graph.

Change-Id: I7ddb2141e55e0613f69750fabe544940192c2d48

commit_message:
Use system resolv.conf file when available

Where possible use the system configured resolv.conf file
to to support resolution of internal servers such as proxies.
Use previous hardcoded google dns nameserver as fallback

Change-Id: Ibc1e8a3b96e733a2f7fbcdd4b2c5d3e8926424c4

heat remove unused config options

Remove metadata* config options - these were actually never used by
the metadata service, and look to be cut/paste artefacts from the
nova codebase.

commit_message:
heat engine : remove KeystoneClient get_user_by_name

Remove get_user_by_name as it's no longer used, and we want to
avoid this style of name->id lookup because it requires keystone
admin role.

Change-Id: I234a235864ac7537df09cae2f07d99ed9d53acd2
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-12-03 14:35:57.000000000', 'message': "heat engine : Rework AccessKey to avoid keystone user lookup

Rework the mapping if AccessKey UserName property to keystone
user_id - the recent refactor reintroduces a keystone.user.list
call, which requires admin role, which we want to avoid or the
in-instance user can't request their own secret key via cfn-hup

ref bug 1085049

Change-Id: I456dff67f56336a9052180dc3c59cea8b7a173bd
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>
"}]
commit_message:
heat engine : Rework AccessKey to avoid keystone user lookup

Rework the mapping if AccessKey UserName property to keystone
user_id - the recent refactor reintroduces a keystone.user.list
call, which requires admin role, which we want to avoid or the
in-instance user can't request their own secret key via cfn-hup

ref bug 1085049

Change-Id: I456dff67f56336a9052180dc3c59cea8b7a173bd
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

Modify API start script to use v2 API

This change moves the script for starting
the V1 API to a new name and replaces it with
a script that starts the V2 API.

Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>

commit_message:
Start updating documentation for V2 API

Move the web API documentation into the 'webapi'
subdirectory to avoid conflicts with the auto-generated
'api' directory contents. Create a v2 doc file
as a placeholder until the automatic documentation
features of WSME are more complete.

blueprint api-server-pecan-wsme

Change-Id: I50655981d4db5dd1caa0379f1f379b42c6d1d580
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>

Move the v2 API into the main source tree

Move the source and tests for the v2 API into the source
tree with the rest of the code and remove the ceilometer_api
directory.

blueprint api-server-pecan-wsme

Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>

commit_message:
Convert errors to parsable format

blueprint api-server-pecan-wsme

Disable error the default error handling from pecan
and use a middleware layer to convert error messages to
JSON, with a note to support XML later, too.

Capture stdout from tests so it appears in nose
output near test failures.

Change-Id: I27ad198eb7379fd52ba34ab875e3547e15ae1a0e
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>

commit_message:
Implement resource listing APIs

Add default pecan project directory,
generated with "pecan create ceilometer_api"

Add the V2 API for listing resources.

Move get_json() to the FunctionalTest class and let the
subclass control the path prefix.

Update get_json() to pass GET arguments to app from tests

blueprint api-server-pecan-wsme

Change-Id: If5b9afab9dd9e69f7df53b05949cbbdac356660f
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-26 12:32:34.000000000', 'message': "Fix set_default() with boolean CLI options

Porting to argparse broke set_default() with boolean CLI options. The
new test case shows this borkage.

The issue is that, by default, argparse differs subtly from optparse in
its handling of defaults for boolean options. Compare:

  >>> p = optparse.OptionParser()
  >>> p.add_option('--foo', action='store_true')
  >>> p.add_option('--bar', action='store_true', default=False)
  >>> p.parse_args([])
  (<Values at 0x7f28aba066c8: {'foo': None, 'bar': False}>, [])

to:

  >>> p = argparse.ArgumentParser()
  >>> p.add_argument('--foo', action='store_true')
  >>> p.add_argument('--bar', action='store_true', default=False)
  >>> p.add_argument('--blaa', action='store_true', default=None)
  >>> p.parse_args([])
  Namespace(bar=False, blaa=None, foo=False)

i.e. unless you specify a default for a boolean option, optparse
defaults to None whereas argparse defaults to False. To get the
same optparse behaviour with argparse, you need default=None.

Change-Id: Ifc92a834c4ba59e939d80ac5de24d7051232f5b5
"}, {'created': '2012-11-26 13:03:19.000000000', 'message': "Fix set_default() with boolean CLI options

Porting to argparse broke set_default() with boolean CLI options. The
new test case shows this borkage.

The issue is that, by default, argparse differs subtly from optparse in
its handling of defaults for boolean options. Compare:

  >>> p = optparse.OptionParser()
  >>> p.add_option('--foo', action='store_true')
  >>> p.add_option('--bar', action='store_true', default=False)
  >>> p.parse_args([])
  (<Values at 0x7f28aba066c8: {'foo': None, 'bar': False}>, [])

to:

  >>> p = argparse.ArgumentParser()
  >>> p.add_argument('--foo', action='store_true')
  >>> p.add_argument('--bar', action='store_true', default=False)
  >>> p.add_argument('--blaa', action='store_true', default=None)
  >>> p.parse_args([])
  Namespace(bar=False, blaa=None, foo=False)

i.e. unless you specify a default for a boolean option, optparse
defaults to None whereas argparse defaults to False. To get the
same optparse behaviour with argparse, you need default=None.

Change-Id: Ifc92a834c4ba59e939d80ac5de24d7051232f5b5
"}, {'created': '2012-12-03 06:26:59.000000000', 'message': "Fix set_default() with boolean CLI options

  >>> p.add_argument('--foo', action='store_true')
  >>> p.add_argument('--bar', action='store_true', default=False)
  >>> p.add_argument('--blaa', action='store_true', default=None)
  >>> p.parse_args([])
  Namespace(bar=False, blaa=None, foo=False)

i.e. unless you specify a default for a boolean option, optparse
defaults to None whereas argparse defaults to False. To get the
same optparse behaviour with argparse, you need default=None.

Change-Id: Ifc92a834c4ba59e939d80ac5de24d7051232f5b5
"}]
commit_message:
Fix set_default() with boolean CLI options

Porting to argparse broke set_default() with boolean CLI options. The
new test case shows this borkage.

The issue is that, by default, argparse differs subtly from optparse in
its handling of defaults for boolean options. Compare:

  >>> p = optparse.OptionParser()
  >>> p.add_option('--foo', action='store_true')
  >>> p.add_option('--bar', action='store_true', default=False)
  >>> p.parse_args([])
  (<Values at 0x7f28aba066c8: {'foo': None, 'bar': False}>, [])

to:

  >>> p = argparse.ArgumentParser()
  >>> p.add_argument('--foo', action='store_true')
  >>> p.add_argument('--bar', action='store_true', default=False)
  >>> p.add_argument('--blaa', action='store_true', default=None)
  >>> p.parse_args([])
  Namespace(bar=False, blaa=None, foo=False)

i.e. unless you specify a default for a boolean option, optparse
defaults to None whereas argparse defaults to False. To get the
same optparse behaviour with argparse, you need default=None.

Change-Id: Ifc92a834c4ba59e939d80ac5de24d7051232f5b5

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-23 22:13:03.000000000', 'message': "Improve cfg's argparse sub-parsers support

In order for sub-parsers to be useful, you need some way of knowing
which sub-parser was chosen during argument parsing. It's pretty obvious
from the current sub-parsers test case that we don't have a convenient
interface for this.

One way of doing it is to use the 'dest' argument when adding
sub-parsers:

  >>> subparsers = parser.add_subparsers(dest='cmd')
  >>> subparsers.add_parser('a')
  >>> subparsers.add_parser('b')
  >>> parser.parse_args(['a'])
  Namespace(cmd='a')

The most sensible way to map this into cfg concepts is to register
sub-parsers as an Opt. This way, we can make name and argument values
of the sub-parser as an attribute on the ConfigOpts object:

  >>> def add_parsers(subparsers):
  ...     a = subparsers.add_parser('a')
  ...     a.add_argument('id')
  ...     b = subparsers.add_parser('b')
  ...
  >>> CONF.register_cli_opt(SubCommandOpt('cmd', handler=add_parsers))
  True
  >>> CONF(['a', '10'])
  >>> CONF.cmd.name, CONF.cmd.id
  ('a', '10')

The handler method is a bit awkward, but each time cfg is to parse
command line args it takes all the registered opts and creates a new
argparse parser. So we need to be able to re-add the sub-parsers each
time.

Change-Id: I01bfd01bf8853cf57a9248b1663eb3da142366a4

commit_message:
Improve cfg's argparse sub-parsers support

In order for sub-parsers to be useful, you need some way of knowing
which sub-parser was chosen during argument parsing. It's pretty obvious
from the current sub-parsers test case that we don't have a convenient
interface for this.

One way of doing it is to use the 'dest' argument when adding
sub-parsers:

  >>> subparsers = parser.add_subparsers(dest='cmd')
  >>> subparsers.add_parser('a')
  >>> subparsers.add_parser('b')
  >>> parser.parse_args(['a'])
  Namespace(cmd='a')

The most sensible way to map this into cfg concepts is to register
sub-parsers as an Opt. This way, we can make name and argument values
of the sub-parser as an attribute on the ConfigOpts object:

  >>> def add_parsers(subparsers):
  ...     a = subparsers.add_parser('a')
  ...     a.add_argument('id')
  ...     b = subparsers.add_parser('b')
  ...
  >>> CONF.register_cli_opt(SubCommandOpt('cmd', handler=add_parsers))
  True
  >>> CONF(['a', '10'])
  >>> CONF.cmd.name, CONF.cmd.id
  ('a', '10')

The handler method is a bit awkward, but each time cfg is to parse
command line args it takes all the registered opts and creates a new
argparse parser. So we need to be able to re-add the sub-parsers each
time.

Change-Id: I01bfd01bf8853cf57a9248b1663eb3da142366a4

commit_message:
Fixes update.py issue with EOL style on Windows

Fixes Bug #1075230

Files are saved with the OS EOL conversion unless "b" is specified
in open(...). In this case we want to preserve the original EOL
convention.

Change-Id: Id756174d03c3e95db055d512ec4aa5a0eeb768b8

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-30 21:12:56.000000000', 'message': "Fix rpc control_exchange regression.

A change was made in rpc that requires project's to define the
control_exchange option themselves.  This was so the project's could
set their own default value.  This change has made it in to nova without
adding the control_exchange option, meaning that it is using the default
of 'openstack', potentially conflicting with other projects.

See https://review.openstack.org/#/c/12518/

Fix bug 1083944.

Change-Id: Ifc00a537c4ee327cbee91fe1d911f8c402e350b7
"}]
commit_message:
Fix rpc control_exchange regression.

A change was made in rpc that requires project's to define the
control_exchange option themselves.  This was so the project's could
set their own default value.  This change has made it in to nova without
adding the control_exchange option, meaning that it is using the default
of 'openstack', potentially conflicting with other projects.

See https://review.openstack.org/#/c/12518/

Fix bug 1083944.

Change-Id: Ifc00a537c4ee327cbee91fe1d911f8c402e350b7

Added sample tests to deferred delete API.

Partially implements blueprint nova-api-samples
Fixes bug 1070157

commit_message:
Add a get_pip_command function

There are two places where we need to find the right command for pip, so
instead of having one version we fix and a buggy version we forget,
simply use a function :-)

Change-Id: I728c17ad7be5c86690c4d7907f77f1f98ec2b815

commit_message:
Fix test suite to use MiniDNS

MiniDNS changes:

* In create_entry/delete_entry, if we don't get a name
then we throw an exception

* In get_entries_by_address, filter out duplicates

* Add a log.warn in addition to throwing an exception.

Test Suite changes:

* Updates base TestCase to use MiniDNS instead of the default DNSDriver.

* Make sure we cleanup the dnstest.txt and the temporary directory
  in TestCase.tearDown()

* Update a few tests to pass in display_name

Fixes LP Bug #1081750

Change-Id: Ia8d80102deaeaaac166ab50bbd47279d72d1e389

commit_message:
Configurable exec_dirs to find rootwrap commands

Adds support for a configurable set of trusted directories to search
executables in (exec_dirs), which defaults to system PATH. If your
filter specifies an exec_path that doesn't start with '/', then it
will be searched in exec_dirs. Avoids having to write multiple
filters to care for distro differences. Fixes bug 1079723.

Also returns a specific error rather than try to run absent executables.

Change-Id: Idab03bb0be6832a75ffeed4e78d25d0543f5caf9

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-12-03 16:58:32.000000000', 'message': "Fix rpc control_exchange regression.

A change was made in rpc that requires project's to define the
control_exchange option themselves.  This was so the project's could
set their own default value.  This change has made it in to quantum without
adding the control_exchange option, meaning that it is using the default
of 'openstack', potentially conflicting with other projects.

See https://review.openstack.org/#/c/12518/

Change-Id: Ia551a3e83de5de17ca7a8ce2b41d64d512983c42
"}]
commit_message:
Fix rpc control_exchange regression.

A change was made in rpc that requires project's to define the
control_exchange option themselves.  This was so the project's could
set their own default value.  This change has made it in to quantum without
adding the control_exchange option, meaning that it is using the default
of 'openstack', potentially conflicting with other projects.

See https://review.openstack.org/#/c/12518/

Change-Id: Ia551a3e83de5de17ca7a8ce2b41d64d512983c42

commit_message:
Fix qpid support on Fedora.

The new qpid_is_supported function returned the opposite value from what
it was supposed to.  It returned success for the platforms where qpid is
not supported.

Change-Id: I0ceaae1dddaa6192657926834c6eb8006925f0cf

commit_message:
On confirm_resize, update correct resource tracker

On confirm_resize, update the resource tracker based on the source
node of the instance, not the destination.

bug 1085325

Change-Id: I041fc27225a8ed8e61fe21945d9241377b1d6384

commit_message:
heat : heat repo moved to openstack

Main heat repo has now moved under the github openstack project
Note the old checkout will require removal to trigger stack.sh to
re-clone it from the new location

Change-Id: I4163e35cad7c319961d42f0c53a68ec6244508ed
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Fix issue with 404 logs on wait for delete.

In some cases the wait on volume deletes will receive a 404
error which results in a log output. However for these tests
this is the expected behavior so the log output isn't needed.

This adds a flag to suppress log output on 404 errors, which
is then used on all wait functions.

Fixes: bug 1084283
Change-Id: Id455a22317ecbdf318e9ad2ea0a76ad9f08ca899

commit_message:
test_absolute_limits.py to check limits response

This commit adds a test case that checks if all the absolute limit
values are returned in the REST call to Nova API Extension
"/limits". Also modifies limits_client.py file for JSON and XML
requests so as to make it less verbose. 'get_specific_absolute_limit'
method is added in the limits_client.py file. As method
'get_personality_file_limit' is removed, "test_server_personality.py"
is modified.

Fixes: bug #1025294
Change-Id: Id334cd73645273d7b80b25ba698d03dc5599a211

The point of this api is to make discovery (esp. from a casual user)

will GET /v1/meters (or /{proj|user|source}/{id}/meters) and

Change-Id: I58f2757874ab151632b6d87043d6327104c5b65c

commit_message:
Implement /meters to make discovery "nicer" from the client

The point of this api is to make discovery (esp. from a casual user)
easier. So you don't really want to dump all the raw samples out
just to see what is there. So instead "ceilometer meter-list"
will GET /v1/meters (or /{proj|user|source}/{id}/meters) and
this will just return a description (name, type, resource, user, etc)
of the available meters, not each sample point. After this you will probably
go and look at the samples that you are actually interested in.

It is a kind of dynamic version of doc/source/measurements.rst

Change-Id: I58f2757874ab151632b6d87043d6327104c5b65c

[{'created': '2012-11-30 13:12:04.000000000', 'message': "check the redirected path on the request, not the response

The request object's path changes when it gets redirected. This
behaviour is in tune with the latest WebOb code as well as the
old. The response environ defaults to None in WebOb >= 1.2b1
http://docs.webob.org/en/latest/news.html#b1

Change-Id: I557563ce5407a8ef1b5dae680e456e589285be25
"}]
commit_message:
check the redirected path on the request, not the response

The request object's path changes when it gets redirected. This
behaviour is in tune with the latest WebOb code as well as the
old. The response environ defaults to None in WebOb >= 1.2b1
http://docs.webob.org/en/latest/news.html#b1

Change-Id: I557563ce5407a8ef1b5dae680e456e589285be25

This looks like an expedient fix, and I'm approving. OTOH, I would rather if we didn't have to work around inconsistencies in the names used by the db schema and the API because that's just going to make things more confusing for new developers down the road. How hard would it be to create a migration to rename the resource_metadata column? The "meter" vs. "meters" name might best be fixed by changing the storage API, but I'll have to think about that one a little more.

Regarding Julien's comment, I opened bug #1085111 earlier today.

Thanks for your work on this, Shane! We're trying to get to the point where the RDBMS backend is fully production ready, and this will be a big help.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-30 20:44:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified

When sqlalchemy (e.g. mysql) is used for ceilometer, show_data.py and web api do
not work because some attributes and keys are different, the patch is fix them

commit_message:
Fix sqlalchemy for show_data and v1 web api

When sqlalchemy (e.g. mysql) is used for ceilometer, show_data.py and web api do
not work because some attributes and keys are different, such as meter/meters,
the patch is fix them and make both can work.

Change-Id: I4b827c3e6664213f1401b183ccbc3a1aaae872aa
Signed-off-by: Shane Wang <shane.wang@intel.com>

[{'created': '2012-12-01 14:54:29.000000000', 'message': "Use json instead of jsonutils in rpc.impl_fake.

The fake rpc backend uses json just to make sure the data that was
passed in can be serialized.  Our jsonutils module makes this check a
no-op, because it will automatically convert the data we pass in as
primitive types if needed.  Change this module back to using the json
module directly and add a comment about why we don't use jsonutils here.

Also add a test that ensures that non-primitive types raise an exception
in the fake rpc driver.

Change-Id: I61f46242cb98c875a94d86283e30efb24cc580ad

commit_message:
Use json instead of jsonutils in rpc.impl_fake.

The fake rpc backend uses json just to make sure the data that was
passed in can be serialized.  Our jsonutils module makes this check a
no-op, because it will automatically convert the data we pass in as
primitive types if needed.  Change this module back to using the json
module directly and add a comment about why we don't use jsonutils here.

Also add a test that ensures that non-primitive types raise an exception
in the fake rpc driver.

Change-Id: I61f46242cb98c875a94d86283e30efb24cc580ad

commit_message:
Don't try to cleanup volume that doesn't exist.

Updates the test_volume_create_get_delete test so that it no
longer tries to cleanup when the volume variable is None.

This resolves UnboundLocalError errors which can occur in
the test suite when volumes aren't getting created correctly.

Change-Id: I483219c4bb78c9dbc21be7a974bd208014ec1740

commit_message:
Make the public quantum network shared.

The public network call 'nova' has been set to shared so that the demo
user can associate quantum resources to it.

Change-Id: Idd56b202a0fc95887acd18badcf126a1840908eb

commit_message:
Replace refs to standard_filters with all_filters

fixes bug 1082217

def standard_filters():
    """Deprecated. Configs should change to use all_filters()."""
    LOG.deprecated(_("Use 'nova.scheduler.filters.all_filters' instead "
            "of 'nova.scheduler.filters.standard_filters'"))
    return all_filters()

So, replace standard_filters with all_filters.

Change-Id: Ie5c5d7273ab5c2c21023604078a2d5c9fb37a707

commit_message:
Add root_helper to _execute() call for not root user.

root_helper is not used at _execute() call in quantum/agent/linux/ip_lib.py.
And this patch addes it.

Fixes bug 1085534

Change-Id: I083e6b92c508abbb093a56f71129889ddc86bfad

commit_message:
Add command to allow users to change their own password

Fixes Bug 1082539

The Equivalent of doing
curl -X PATCH http://localhost:5000/v2.0/OS-KSCRUD/users/<userid> \
    -H "Content-type: application/json"  \
    -H "X_Auth_Token: <authtokenid>" \
    -d '{"user": {"password": "ABCD", "original_password": "DCBA"}}'

Change-Id: Ia1a907c5fd138c4252196145b361f43671047a1a

commit_message:
Fix/revert back to globally unique names

These two changes were intended to revert to globally unique names:

    https://review.openstack.org/#/c/13400/
    https://review.openstack.org/#/c/15051/

It looks like these changes were undone by a bad merge similar to what was
fixed in:

    https://review.openstack.org/#/c/16200/

Also fixed a typo.

Change-Id: I201057a9af09760d40474f41cbcca0cd709aec9e
